bibl.title: Letter from Arthur W. Packard to Philip Showalter Hench, November 13, 1947

div1.p: Packard apologizes for not replying to Hench's letter sooner, but felt it was necessary to resolve underlying policy matters relating to Hench's project before responding. He reiterates that the Rockefeller Foundation will not provide financial support for the Camp Lazear memorial.

div1.head: Letter from Arthur W. Packard to Philip Showalter Hench, November 13, 1947
div1.opener:
30 Rockefeller Plaza
New York 20, N. Y.
November 13, 1947
ROOM 5600
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am sorry for the delay which has attended an earlier
reply to your letter of October 29th. The fact of the matter
is that the information which came with your letter was so
complete for our purposes, certainly at this juncture, that
I felt it would be less than fair to you to proceed with the
arrangements for a conference on the matter without first
clearing on the underlying policy question which would be in-
volved with respect to the assumption of an added interest of
this character and without any reference to the merit or the
appealing nature of the project itself of which you wrote.

This procedure was necessarily somewhat time-consuming and
I was on the point of writing you as to its result when your
telegram arrived. Consequently, I sent you yesterday the
following telegram which summarizes the situation here and my
view as to the feasibility of our conferring about the matter:

“Your letter provided thoroughly adequate material for
preliminary consideration which indicates no likeli-
hood our financial participation. Your points fully
appreciated. Decision involves principles necessarily
limiting scope nature our commitments. Believe there-
fore conference not helpfully serve your purpose nor
warrant special New York visit. If in light of above
you care to call shall be glad to see you on either
18th or 20th. Writing.”

I am sorry that the situation does not appear to be one we
could take up with a view to being helpful, but I am sure you
appreciate the many opportunities for appealing and significant
service which are rendered these days make it necessary for our
own activities to be concentrated along certain definite lines.
